segment.source: Create a basic audit policy for an event category (Windows 10)
segment.target: Create a basic audit policy for an event category (Windows 10)

segment.source: By defining auditing settings for specific event categories, you can create an auditing policy that suits the security needs of your organization.
segment.target: By defining auditing settings for specific event categories, you can create an auditing policy that suits the security needs of your organization.

segment.source: Create a basic audit policy for an event category
segment.target: Create a basic audit policy for an event category

segment.source: Applies to
segment.target: Applies to

segment.source: Windows 10
segment.target: Windows 10

segment.source: By defining auditing settings for specific event categories, you can create an auditing policy that suits the security needs of your organization.
segment.target: By defining auditing settings for specific event categories, you can create an auditing policy that suits the security needs of your organization.

segment.source: On devices that are joined to a domain, auditing settings for the event categories are undefined by default.
segment.target: On devices that are joined to a domain, auditing settings for the event categories are undefined by default.

segment.source: On domain controllers, auditing is turned on by default.
segment.target: On domain controllers, auditing is turned on by default.

segment.source: To complete this procedure, you must be logged on as a member of the built-in Administrators group.
segment.target: To complete this procedure, you must be logged on as a member of the built-in Administrators group.

segment.source: To define or modify auditing policy settings for an event category for your local computer
segment.target: To define or modify auditing policy settings for an event category for your local computer

segment.source: Open the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc), and then click Local Policies.
segment.target: Open the Local Security Policy snap-in (secpol.msc), and then click Local Policies.

segment.source: Click Audit Policy.
segment.target: Click Audit Policy.

segment.source: In the results pane, double-click an event category that you want to change the auditing policy settings for.
segment.target: In the results pane, double-click an event category that you want to change the auditing policy settings for.

segment.source: Do one or both of the following, and then click OK.
segment.target: Do one or both of the following, and then click OK.

segment.source: To audit successful attempts, select the Success check box.
segment.target: To audit successful attempts, select the Success check box.

segment.source: To audit unsuccessful attempts, select the Failure check box.
segment.target: To audit unsuccessful attempts, select the Failure check box.

segment.source: To complete this procedure, you must be logged on as a member of the Domain Admins group.
segment.target: To complete this procedure, you must be logged on as a member of the Domain Admins group.

segment.source: To define or modify auditing policy settings for an event category for a domain or organizational unit, when you are on a member server or on a workstation that is joined to a domain
segment.target: To define or modify auditing policy settings for an event category for a domain or organizational unit, when you are on a member server or on a workstation that is joined to a domain

segment.source: Open the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).
segment.target: Open the Group Policy Management Console (GPMC).

segment.source: In the console tree, double-click Group Policy objects in the forest and domain containing the Default Domain Policy Group Policy object (GPO) that you want to edit.
segment.target: In the console tree, double-click Group Policy objects in the forest and domain containing the Default Domain Policy Group Policy object (GPO) that you want to edit.

segment.source: Right-click the Default Domain Policy GPO, and then click Edit.
segment.target: Right-click the Default Domain Policy GPO, and then click Edit.

segment.source: In the GPMC, go to Computer Configuration, Windows Settings, Security Settings, and then click Audit Policy.
segment.target: In the GPMC, go to Computer Configuration, Windows Settings, Security Settings, and then click Audit Policy.

segment.source: In the results pane, double-click an event category that you want to change the auditing policy settings for.
segment.target: In the results pane, double-click an event category that you want to change the auditing policy settings for.

segment.source: If you are defining auditing policy settings for this event category for the first time, select the Define these policy settings check box.
segment.target: If you are defining auditing policy settings for this event category for the first time, select the Define these policy settings check box.

segment.source: Do one or both of the following, and then click OK.
segment.target: Do one or both of the following, and then click OK.

segment.source: To audit successful attempts, select the Success check box.
segment.target: To audit successful attempts, select the Success check box.

segment.source: To audit unsuccessful attempts, select the Failure check box.
segment.target: To audit unsuccessful attempts, select the Failure check box.

segment.source: Additional considerations
segment.target: Additional considerations

segment.source: To audit object access, enable auditing of the object access event category by following the steps above.
segment.target: To audit object access, enable auditing of the object access event category by following the steps above.

segment.source: Then, enable auditing on the specific object.
segment.target: Then, enable auditing on the specific object.

segment.source: After your audit policy is configured, events will be recorded in the Security log.
segment.target: After your audit policy is configured, events will be recorded in the Security log.

segment.source: Open the Security log to view these events.
segment.target: Open the Security log to view these events.

segment.source: The default auditing policy setting for domain controllers is No Auditing.
segment.target: The default auditing policy setting for domain controllers is No Auditing.

segment.source: This means that even if auditing is enabled in the domain, the domain controllers do not inherit auditing policy locally.
segment.target: This means that even if auditing is enabled in the domain, the domain controllers do not inherit auditing policy locally.

segment.source: If you want domain auditing policy to apply to domain controllers, you must modify this policy setting.
segment.target: If you want domain auditing policy to apply to domain controllers, you must modify this policy setting.
